Topic.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Message.Msg: @frtgrdn21: Amazon mostly uses Restricted Stock Units (RSUs) rather than options for both employees and to pay for some of its acquisitions like that for Zappos etc. Unlike options which have a strike price, RSUs don't cost a dime to the recipient either at the time of award nor when they vests. At the time of award, Amazon assigns it some fair market value and records it as paid-in capital (mind you, these are phantom dollars as no money has been received) and offsets that as an unrecognized compensation cost. As the RSUs vest, the appropriate dollar amount from the unrecognized compensation cost gets expensed. This disclosure in its 10-Q should give an idea of its size, pace and timetable: ""As of June 30, 2012, there was $1.25 billion of net unrecognized compensation cost related to unvested stock-based compensation arrangements. This compensation is recognized on an accelerated basis, with approximately half of the compensation expected to be expensed in the next twelve months, and has a weighted average recognition period of 1.3 years. " All the money for its buyback dilution sterilization program has to now come from its profits or cash flow as there was no capital which was brought in as would have happened in an options award and exercise situation. As an RSU has a zero cost to the recipient, it is much better than holding an option in the event the strike price ends up higher than the stock price at the time of exercise, and then the recipient has to count on the goodwill of management to reprice them. It is perhaps with this is mind that Amazon has chosen the RSU route rather than Options, as even in the event of some sizeable collapse of its stock price, the RSUs will still be worth something and hopefully that serves as an adequate golden tether and avoid disruptive flight of talent. At the rate at which Amazon has been issuing the RSUs (4.3 million in 2Q12 alone) and with 2.1 million Restricted Stock Units reported vested and probably waiting to be flipped it will quickly run through its buyback war-chest, which, as they can’t be replenished with profits, will have to be done with debt. So, I see Amazon soon needing to tap the debt market. And why not? With its rating it should have no trouble borrowing at today’s “please take my money” amazing rates. But I wonder if the closer scrutiny that generally accompanies a debt placement might be the tipping point for this ponzi scam?

Message.Title: Cash Burn on massive scale - Ponzi scheme is starting to crack
Message.Msg: The option game (cash generation) and share buyback (keep share count low) to keep the stock afloat is having issues + when added to the insane investment required to maintain growth - this company is struggling to meet investor expectations set by the P/E. Cash was $9.6B in Q4, down to $5.7B in Q1 and down to $4.9B in Q2. Down from $21/sh to $11/sh now. With no net income, stock based compensation is their #2 source of cash ($221 million in Q2) after depreciation. When cash tightens a little more over next couple of Q's and they can't buy back all of the new shares added (and continue this massive investment), this pupply will start to drop quickly as investors reset their return expectations.
Oops . . . stock futures all green again. Geez. No major pullback?

Topic.Title: PE of almost 300 and still buyers here .. WOW!

Message.Msg: Last weekend was a sales tax holiday in Alabama for computers and school supplies. Best Buy in Huntsville was packed. The computer section had aisles blocked for better control. This gave me a good indication of how important that 8% sales tax can be. Amazon has to collect now in many states. Texas was the latest and many more governors are lined up. No stopping it now. Schulze & pals from BBY have this morning started a buyout bid for the company (BBY). They know the details as to how the stores have fared in the states where AMZN is collecting taxes. Will this slow or stunt AMZN's growth? I would think so. And a 200-300 PE needs a lot of growth to support.

Topic.Title: Amazon Might Not Be the Growth Engine Investors Think

Message.Msg: They will cut RSU's before accessing debt market - however I believe in 2014 they will be forced to access the debt market (or issue stock) as their net cash and working capital will be insufficient to support operations. They will continue to loose money for the remainder of 2012 and 2013 isn't looking much better unless they cut many R&D programs.

It has seemed in the past that when money goes in the cloud sector stocks, it seems to go in everytime all at once over a 6-8 week period! CRM is easy fast, well deserved money, 40 points off high and a second place stock 20 billion dollars undervalued as compared to VMW!
